fieldData.title: Waiving overdue tax debts
fieldData.descriptionBackgroundInfo: The German Federal Government modified the tax law, in order to help businesses with their tax debts and improve their liquidity. All companies with tax debts can apply for this measure until the end of 2020. It is part of the support package to stabilise the German economy and help out firms during the COVID-19 crisis. The package was adopted by the Federal Government at the end of March 2020.
fieldData.descriptionContentOfMeasure: The German Federal Government temporarily changed taxation rules for companies. Overdue tax debts (and default charges) can be waived until the end of 2020. Companies need to apply for postponing their tax debt payments until the end of 2020 at their local tax authority office. This measure includes any debts regards the income, corporate tax and sales tax. It is part of a broader package that also includes other changes in tax law, all of them directed at easing tax burdens for companies in times of crisis; and also includes easier access to loans, start-up support or financial help for solo- or micro entrepreneurs.
fieldData.descriptionUseOfMeasure: The Federal Ministry of Finance estimated that the new tax rules will lead to a decline in tax revenues by 10% at the federal level as well as at the level of the federal states in 2020. Such a decline would equal around €64 billion. Not included in these figures are further tax losses at the municipal level.
fieldData.descriptionInvolvementOfSocialPartners: German social partners are usually consulted by the Federal Government on broader measures, though no formal tripartite social dialogue structure exsits in Germany at the federal level. Social partners were involved and asked to provide input regards the new COVID-19 measures. However, time for commenting on proposals was very short.
fieldData.statusOfRegulation: New aspects included into existing measure

updates.updates::description: There is no detailed information or estimate on how many companies have asked to waiver their overdue tax debts. However, in the latest tax estimate from September 2020, Federal Minister of Finance Olaf Scholz expects tax revenue for 2020 to decrease by €81.6 billion. In 2021, tax revenue is expected to be €19.6 billion lower than estimated in May 2020. A pre-COVID tax revenue level is expected for 2022 at the earliest.

In November and December 2020, the Federal Government prologned its aid packages and added new elements. Rules to waive overdue taxes in companies negatively impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic were prologned, too. Companies who apply for tax deferral by the end of March 2021 will not have to reimburse their overdue taxes until 30 June 2021.
